items.title: Canada, U.S. still talking despite Trump ending trade negotiations: envoy
items.description: Kirsten Hillman, who also serves as Canada's top negotiator with the U.S., said her people have spoken with officials in the White House and other departments since last week.

items.title: Negotiators were taking ‘important steps’ before Trump halted talks, ambassador says
The Winter Olympics are 100 days away — here are 10 Canadians to watch
items.description: CBC Sports' daily newsletter presents some top Canadian athletes to follow on the road to the upcoming Winter Olympic Games in Italy.

items.title: Penticton, B.C. city council to consider tiny home community
items.description: 'One of our permanent shelters has individuals who’ve been there for more than 600 days,' said Julie Czeck, the city’s general manager of public safety.

items.title: Canada’s U17 women’s soccer squad to meet Brazil in World Cup quarterfinal
items.description: Canada scored three goals in each half en route to a comfortable 6-0 win over Zambia in Round of 16 play Wednesday, setting up a quarterfinal date with Brazil at the FIFA Women's U17 World Cup in Sale, Morocco.

items.title: Avoid travel to parts of Caribbean as Hurricane Melissa storms through region, GAC says
items.description: The federal government is advising Canadians to avoid travelling to certain areas in the Caribbean as Hurricane Melissa rips through the region.

items.title: Parks Canada warns of increasingly ‘bold’ wolves stalking dogs near Tofino, B.C.
items.description: Visitors to Pacific Rim National Park Reserve on Vancouver Island are being urged to leave their dogs at home and keep their children close after several incidents of wolves stalking people's pets near Tofino.

items.title: Halloween enthusiasts warned fireworks illegal in many Okanagan cities, including Kelowna
items.description: Johnson said burning and fireworks complaints are common on Halloween but he added that the fire activity isn't only illegal--it's also dangerous.

items.title: Ottawa woman speaks out against former head of Manitoba Inuit Association
items.description: Inuit women and gender-diverse people say a grassroots social media movement publicizing allegations of sexual and physical assault against the CEO of the Manitoba Inuit Association is giving them the courage to come forward with their own accusations against him.

items.title: Cost estimate more than triples to $1.3B for new federal inmate hospital
items.description: The budget for a new hospital for inmates in federal facilities is now estimated at $1.3 billion, over three times an estimate made public in 2021.

items.title: Five things to know about the fight between Quebec doctors and the government
items.description: Here are five things to know about the ongoing battle between physicians and the provincial government.

items.title: ‘Forever Canadian’ Results Shock the UCP Government
items.description: Thomas Lukaszuk delivers petitions signed by over 456,000 citizens, upsetting separatist referendum plans.

items.title: Young entrepreneurs find success in Winnipeg ice cream shops
items.description: Some young entrepreneurs take advantage of Manitoba's brief summer and run successful ice cream shops that only open for a short and sweet part of the year.

items.title: Alberta’s Big Payouts to Spurned Australian Coal Miners
items.description: Two firms that invested far less are getting $235 million. Taxpayers face more such hits.

items.title: Eby Threatens Snap Election over North Coast Transmission Line
items.description: If opposition MLAs block legislation on the project, voters could be heading to the polls.

items.title: Saskatchewan filmmaker documents 77-year-old plane wreck for first time
items.description: A Saskatchewan filmmaker highlights the forgotten tale of a U.S. Navy plane that went down in 1948, prompting the largest search and rescue mission at the time.

items.title: Meet the artist who carved the Toronto Blue Jays logo into the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia
items.description: The mystery of who carved a Toronto Blue Jays logo into the sandstone of the Art Gallery of Nova Scotia has been solved.
